Andy, 

I see, I understand the rationale.  I will be interested to see how=
 
things go with your ideas.  The main question will be whether the 
system=
 crosses the line between enough and too much of a good thing. 
That is, in=
creasing the diversity of computational building blocks 
can be userful, bu=
t beyond some point it starts to make things harder 
rather than easier.  O=
f course, it's hard to say exactly where that 
line is.  We can only find o=
ut by trying, so it will be an 
interesting experiment.

ken

upervisor NEAT is reformulated as follows:

ce to supervisor class;

d into population 
class;

ss, also member of

utput nodes;

ntain

ition of node expanded to include ability to maintain 
> activation functio=
n, network or population;

olvable network-in-a-node, static vote-taker

> in-a-node, or a=
n adaptive incremental evolvable vote-taker 
population-
> in-a-node.

and

mbedability. This combined with the need to expand the functional

lary of the hypercube network are why (d) and (e) above are

dequate means to supervise application of a rich and 
> diverse functional =
vocabulary, which can also include prior evolved 
> networks and/or populat=
ions, whether static or adaptive incremental 
> evolved, can be developed. =
There is no reason to tie our hands with 
> an inordinately small set of mo=
nolith activation functions that 
> conveniently fit within the confines of=
 one-input/one-output per 
node.

>    Andy Carl
